questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 2 weeks ago. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 162/mm3. An interferon-gamma release assay is negative. Prophylactic treatment against which of the following pathogens is most appropriate at this time?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pneumocystis jirovecii Pneumocystis jiroveci :Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is a lung infection caused by a fungus. It's rare in healthy people, and usually affects those with a weak immune system.

Highyeild:

Pneumocystis jiroveci Till recently P.Jiroveci was though to be a Protozoan Molecular biology proved that it is a Fungus, related to Ascomycetes Pneumocystis species are present in the lungs of many animals, Rats, Mice, Dogs, Cats, and Rabbits, Do not cause infections until immuno supressed. More familiar Pneumocystis carinii is found only in Rats.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option:A. Patients with HIV infection who have a CD4+ count < 100/mm3 and test positive for Toxoplasma gondii IgG antibodies should receive primary prophylaxis against this pathogen with TMP-SMX. Since this patient has a CD4+ count of 162/mm3, he does not require prophylaxis against T. gondii. Option:C. Patients with HIV infection should receive regular screening for latent tuberculosis, and patients with a positive screening test who are receiving antiretroviral therapy should receive isoniazid monotherapy. However, this patient has a negative interferon-γ release assay and, therefore, does not require prophylaxis. Option:D. Patients with a CD4+ count < 100/mm3 have an increased risk of developing invasive aspergillosis. This patient has a CD4+ count of 162/mm3. In addition, prophylaxis against Aspergillus fumigatus is not generally recommended for patients with HIV infection, regardless of their CD4+ count, because of the risk of drug interactions, adverse effects, and drug resistance. Prophylaxis against A. fumigatus does not have a proven survival benefit.

Extraedge:

Patients with HIV infection who have a CD4+ count < 200/mm3 should receive primary prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii with TMP-SMX. Patients who have contraindications to taking this drug (e.g., due to sulfa allergy) should receive atovaquone, dapsone, or aerosolized pentamidine instead.

Table:

Pneumocystis jiroveci Pneumonia Protozoa? Fungus? Used to be most common opportunistic infection, but much less common now that prophylaxis used. Clinical Findings Gradual onset Fever, chills, weight loss Cough, SOB Radiologic Findings Findings Diffuse interstitial infiltrates (on x-ray) Cysts Ground glass infiltrates (on CT scan) Pleural Effusions Pneumothorax Diagnosis Positive immunofluorescent staining of sputum or bronchealveolar lavage. Often elevated LDH (LDH level correlates with severity)

questions.text: Which of the following is nephrotoxic?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Streptomycin

Highyeild:

Common properties of aminoglycoside antibiotics All are used as highly water-soluble sulfate salts; solutions are stable for months. They ionize in solution; are not absorbed orally; distribute only extracellularly; do not penetrate the brain or CSF. All are excreted unchanged in the urine by glomerular filtration. All are bactericidal and more active at alkaline ph. They act by interfering with bacterial protein synthesis. All are active primarily against aerobic Gram-negative bacilli and do not inhibit anaerobes. There is only partial cross-resistance among them. They have a relatively narrow margin of safety. All exhibit ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic, used in the treatment of bacterial infections. It is also used in treating infections of the urinary tract, nose, throat, skin and soft tissues, and lungs (pneumonia). It prevents the bacterial cells from dividing and repairing, thereby killing them. Option: C . Piperacillin is a broad-spectrum β-lactam antibiotic of the ureidopenicillin class. The chemical structure of piperacillin and other ureidopenicillins incorporates a polar side chain that enhances penetration into Gram-negative bacteria and reduces susceptibility to cleavage by Gram-negative beta-lactamase Option: D . Cefotaxime is an antibiotic used to treat several bacterial infections in humans, other animals, and plant tissue cultures. Specifically in humans, it is used to treat joint infections, pelvic inflammatory disease, meningitis, pneumonia, urinary tract infections, sepsis, gonorrhea, and cellulitis.

Table:

Aminoglycosides Protein Synthesis Inhibitors (Bactericidal) Inhibit protein synthesis by irreversibly binding to 30S subunit of the ribosome. Gentamicin Netilmicin Streptomycin Tobramycin Side effects include ototoxicity, which may lead to vestibular and auditory dysfunction. Renal damage through concentration of the drug in the proximal tubular cells of the kidney - usually reversible. Poorly absorbed from the gut and, as a result, are administered parenterally. They have short half-lives (1-4 hours) and rapidly eliminated via the kidney. They do not cross the blood-brain barrier, but they do cross the placenta. Spectrum of Activity Particularly useful in treating aerobic gram- negative infections: Pseudomonas, Acinetobacter and Enterobacter etc. Inactive against anaerobic organisms.

questions.text: A Patient on antimicrobial therapy develops the following signs and symptoms that ultimately are found to be drug-induced (Cough, dyspnea, pulmonary Infiltrates, neutropenia, and bleeding tendencies). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nitrofurantoin Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic that fights bacteria. It is used to treat and prevent uncomplicated urinary tract infections. It works by killing the bacteria that cause such diseases. But, it will not treat a viral infection.

Highyeild:

GI side effects (anorexia, nausea, vomiting) are the most common side effects caused by this drug, which is still widely used for managing acute lower urinary tract infections (e.g., many strains of E. Coli, staphylococci streptococci, Neisseria, Bacteroides). Acute pulmonary reactions to nitrofurantoin are an uncommon side effect of therapy and can cause minor or life-threatening pulmonary dysfunction. Symptoms include fever, chills, cough, pleuritic chest pain, and Rarely, pleural effusion and/or pulmonary hemorrhage may occur.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Amoxicillin is an antibiotic medicine with versatile actions. It can treat a multitude of bacterial infections including those of the ears, eyes, nose, sinus, tonsils, tooth, throat, lungs, skin, gastrointestinal tract, and urinary tract. It may also be effective against peptic ulcer disease. Option: B. Azithromycin is an antibiotic used to treat various types of infections of the respiratory tract, ear, skin, and eye in adults and children. It is also effective in typhoid fever and some sexually transmitted diseases like gonorrhea. Option: C. Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic, used in the treatment of bacterial infections. It is also used in treating infections of the urinary tract, nose, throat, skin and soft tissues, and lungs (pneumonia). It prevents the bacterial cells from dividing and repairing, thereby killing them.

questions.text: Streptomycin and other aminoglycosides inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

30S Ribosomal Particles

Highyeild:

The bactericidal activity of streptomycin and other aminoglycosides involves direct action on the 30S ribosomal subunit, the site at which these agents both inhibit protein synthesis and diminish the accuracy of translation of the genetic code. Proteins containing improper sequences of amino acids (known as nonsense proteins) are often nonfunctional.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. 30S Ribosomal Particle s are the smaller subunit of the 70S ribosome found in prokaryotes. It is a complex of the 16S ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and 19 proteins. This complex is implicated in the binding of transfer RNA to messenger RNA (mRNA) Option: B. DNA is a self-replicating material that is present in nearly all living organisms as the main constituent of chromosomes. It is the carrier of genetic information. Option: C . Messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA) is a single-stranded molecule of RNA that corresponds to the genetic sequence of a gene and is read by a ribosome in the process of synthesizing a protein
